author: _____josh_____
content:
Read about the Ropsten issue a week ago because most of the media refuses to write about it (this is something to be concerned about). Checking back a week later and still slightly disappointed with the way things are being handled. Not an ETH dev but a dev for the extended ecosystem. I know I don't have a say in any of this but just felt the need to get it out of my system.

My understanding is that some stakeholders have/had reservations about London code being ready for mainnet but devs are unwilling to push back deployment because their hands are tied due to having written themselves into a corner with the difficulty bomb. I understand that the merits of keeping the difficulty bomb is a separate discussion altogether but if it was meant to force migration to 2.0, it shouldn't even be an issue for a non-merge related fork in the first place. 3554 (as 3238 back then) should have been pushed out in June regardless of 1559's delays. It shouldn't have been used to force action for non-merge updates. Postponing it by 2 years in 2019 was a step in the right direction and to be back at square one today is a tad bit disappointing.

author: _____josh_____
content:
The fact that the consensus issue managed to escape detection so long into testing is definitely concerning as we don't know how many more of such edge cases are hiding in plain sight. It's not even the first time a hard fork resulted in a consensus failure (remember Berlin?) so it was really disappointing that teams weren't extra careful about the changes this time.

ETH is second largest market cap with even more DeFi built over it, not some weekend project to trial balloon new experimental fee structures that might break everything. A LOT rests on the stability of the mainnet. London is not just random small bug fixes but a complete rework of core functionality. With how much 1559 was delayed and with POS supposedly to hit in 4 months, is there really a need to rework the fee structure and potentially break things?

In the real world, where the directors have to answer to the investors, if something like this was discovered so close to launch the launch date would have been put on hold indefinitely and everyone would be put on double overtime to make sure there wasn't other issues. But this being an open source project, where corporate governance is non-existent, means that you can't just have people put in more effort or be accountable for any resulting errors.

author: _____josh_____
content:
Something to consider is that the last two ACDs were when ETH price was at risk of breaking below 1.7k. How much of decision to push forward on the same release date was motivated by the fear of causing an uncontrolled price crash? How many people are pushing it so hard because they want prices back at 4k and do not care about sustainability of the ecosystem? Now that prices are more or less back to stable territory ~2.7k, it should have given room to push back the date for proper testing. A temporary price setback would be better than the fallout from breaking everything.

If you guys were worried about the backlash, an announcement calling for feedback from the community that actually uses the ecosystem with full disclosure about hiccups would have been the right way to handle it. Not have repeated meetings among the same handful of core devs that have the same bias on the issue. ETH is already being criticised for being too centralised with governance. Eventually this will be more of a negative than a positive.

Thanks for coming to my Ted Talk.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> My understanding is that some stakeholders have/had reservations about London code being ready for mainnet but devs are unwilling to push back deployment because their hands are tied due to having written themselves into a corner with the difficulty bomb.
We could pretty easily craft a PR that *only* pushed back the bomb.  Also, the bomb is on a slow fuse, so even if the bomb "goes off", we can delay action.  I personally don't think the difficulty bomb played any role in the decision to not push back London.

author: _____josh_____
content: https://twitter.com/TimBeiko/status/1414635059324198913

author: sky.cactus
content: I think that is just because procrastination is a real thing.

author: sky.cactus
content: We wouldn't have tried so hard to target July without the bomb, and would have dragged our feet on several of the EIPs included in London.

author: sky.cactus
content: Delaying London just for the sake of delaying isn't useful.  It was discussed, and no one was able to come up with a concrete plan for additional risk reduction based on the finding of the bug on Ropsten, so any delay would not have achieved a concrete goal and instead would have just been a delay "for show".  It was proposed that if someone had a concrete risk reduction plan then a delay of London would be considered.

author: sky.cactus
content: And to head off the common retort, "more testing" isn't a concrete plan.  ðŸ˜„  A concrete plan would be describing specific tests that should be done, and why those tests need more than 2 weeks to be built/run.

author: _____josh_____
content: Even in this channel there were some devs from besu/erigon that mentioned the bomb influencing their decision on the issue

author: sky.cactus
content: There are definitely people who don't like the bomb and take every opportunity to argue against it.  ðŸ™‚  During the debates about the Ropsten bug though I don't remember hearing any compelling reasons why this specific issue was significantly impacted by the bomb.

author: _____josh_____
content: Understand the lack of concrete plans making a delay meaningless but that's just the nature of open source projects. I read the discussions earlier and it seemed as though different teams were just deflecting that responsibility to others and then collectively deciding to just let it be. Perhaps some incentive should have been given.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't agree with that assessment.  I think people really did try to think about whether there was a void in testing that we could reasonably fill, but no one was able to come up with one.

author: sky.cactus
content: I believe all of the core developers care greatly about the stability of Ethereum, and while different teams have different risk profiles and aversions, I suspect that they care more about Ethereum stability than most people in the ecosystem.

author: gwintery
content:
It will never be possible to catch 100% of bugs, you seem to be arguing to have more testing to catch more edge cases. But the effort to catch that extra 0.5% of bugs may take 100% more effort and is not always desirable.

Side note : I don't think your real world example here is even close to reality. As someone who's worked on many real world projects it is always up to us the engineers to decide whether a huge delay is necessary or not. Most of the time, we will be pushed to ship things even earlier when possible as long as it runs first and solve more problems along the way.  The severity of the issue will of course need to be accounted. And ETH is in real world, it is not in some fantasy land.

author: _____josh_____
content:
```
Side note : I don't think your real world example here is even close to reality. As someone who's worked on many real world projects it is always up to us the engineers to decide whether a huge delay is necessary or not. Most of the time, we will be pushed to ship things even earlier when possible as long as it runs first and solve more problems along the way.  The severity of the issue will of course need to be accounted. And ETH is in real world, it is not in some fantasy land.
```
I was trying to draw attention to the fact that there is no similar governance structure in unregulated instruments like crypto. No directors' duties and therefore no recourse for negligence or breach of fiduciary duties if something breaks due to hasty commits. In this area, I believe we can agree that ETH is quite far from real world.

author: sky.cactus
content: While there aren't any people whose heads one can put on a pike if things break, all of the client developers I know of care far more about system stability than the vast majority silicon valley CTOs.

author: _____josh_____
content:
```
I believe all of the core developers care greatly about the stability of Ethereum, and while different teams have different risk profiles and aversions, I suspect that they care more about Ethereum stability than most people in the ecosystem.
```
I think that's a little dismissive of the various projects built over ETH blockchain. Billions of dollars riding on the unassailability of the EVM.

author: sky.cactus
content: The ultimate stability solution would be to never patch.  We have to find a balance between making useful changes to the network and maintaining network stability.  When arguing for more stability, one has to pit that against the value of changes being made.  Just because there are billions of dollars on the network doesn't mean that we should stop updating.

author: sky.cactus
content: The majority of the core developers, who I still assert care greatly about Ethereum stability, agreed that launching London was the best course of action all things considered, and I don't think any of them are unaware of the amount of value flowing around Ethereum.

author: _____josh_____
content:
```
The ultimate stability solution would be to never patch.  We have to find a balance between making useful changes to the network and maintaining network stability.  When arguing for more stability, one has to pit that against the value of changes being made.  Just because there are billions of dollars on the network doesn't mean that we should stop updating.
```
Again, like I said earlier, this isn't a small change or minor fix. With how much 1559 has been delayed, the window between London and 2.0 is so tiny that it might no longer be worth the risk of messing with the fee structure. Reminder that nobody even knows if 1559 will lower transaction fees at all or just result in a complete standstill in transactions because it's all theories mixed with hope. The original balance of pros vs cons was probably around 60 to 40. Imo, with the delays and the developments it should have pushed it over the threshold.

```
The majority of the core developers, who I still assert care greatly about Ethereum stability, agreed that launching London was the best course of action all things considered, and I don't think any of them are unaware of the amount of value flowing around Ethereum.
```

Being made aware and having any skin in the game are two different things. I reckon the percentage of holdings in ETH probably dwarfs holdings in various on chain projects if any.

```
While there aren't any people whose heads one can put on a pike if things break, all of the client developers I know of care far more about system stability than the vast majority silicon valley CTOs.
```
It's not about putting heads on a pike. It's more about being made whole when things break. Companies invested in these projects do have a responsibility for their assets.

author: gwintery
content:
1559 was never meant to lower transaction fees, it is meant to improve UX and eliminate the fee auction mechanism? What is the connection between London and 2.0 timing being close that fee structure is not worth to mess with? Both literally does not affect each other?

Saying it is all theories mixed with hope is ironic, as if we don't work based on that, ETH would not even be conceived at all. We are at the forefront of the innovation and almost everything being done is going to be trailblazing new paths. If we are scared of that we should then adopt the stability ethos of bitcoin and barely change anything.

author: samwilsn
content: I don't mean to open a can of worms or anything, but is there a good place to read about the pros and cons that have been discussed about having fixed dates for hard forks (ex. one in February and one in August, every year)?

author: 00b0b.
content: Any idea what the cause of this is? just organic demand? anything anyone thinks we should be concerned about?

author: timbeiko
content: Going to be a bit more aggressive in deleting messages given the high volume of spam today. This is a technical sever to discuss development, not voice every opinion you have about Ethereum, please see <#745072678079168654>

author: harithk
content:
just shared etherscan's new eip 1559 dashboard
https://twitter.com/etherscan/status/1423331497205927937

author: 0xsadcat
content: 1. multiple pools were/are downvoting the gas limit. this increased congestion. 2. flashbots broke because their simulation was setting base fee at 0 (not 100% sure about this one) which caused MEV to turn to PGA again. 3. normal nfts shenanigans

author: harithk
content: yeah we're fixing this tomorrow... not showing a useful number. will likely replace with base fee as suggested by <@!552133098075193354>

author: gregthegreek
content:
<@!552133098075193354> lmk if i should move this elsewhere

I've been thinking about type 0x1 transactions for signers (web3.js). It might make sense to just default them to type 0x2 i can't understand why someone would ever explicitly want a type 0x1...

author: timbeiko
content: There are a lot of "almost empty" ones too ðŸ˜… I also kind of expected ~15m per block, but it's more 20/5 right now. This might be due to the rollout being new, tooling not being updated, etc. I'm curious to see over time if it stabilizes, but the client devs I've asked about this so far today don't think it's a concern

author: suburbandad_
content: This might be an edge effect of gas target being right at equilibrium, and base fee adjusting up/down just slightly past and then slightly below the maxFeePerGas of a bulk of transactions in the pool

content: should be interesting to see once tooling is in place, and most TXs are type '2' what it'll all stabilize around
